titleStmt.title: Despatch from Seth A. Pratt to George L. Rives, March 21, 1889

bibl.title: Despatch from Seth A. Pratt to George L. Rives
Despatches from United States Consuls in Zanzibar, Br. Africa, 1836-1906

div1.p:
Consulate of the United States
Zanzibar, March 21 1889

Honorable G. L. Rives
Assistant Secretary of State
Washington, D.C.

I have the honor to inform the Department that the last mail steamer from Aden brought one hundred Somalis who have been engaged by the German East African Company to help fight their battles on the coast

They were not allowed to land at Zanzibar but were transferred in one of the Sultan's steamers to the main land. It is very doubtful if the Somalis can be made to fight against the Coast Arabs being of the same religion.

On the 18th inst I received a Cablegram from Commander McCalla of the U.S.S. Enterprise stating
stating that he was at Port Said on his way to Zanzibar and Madagascar, and asking if there is any reason why he should not go first to Tamatave. As everything is quiet here in Zanzibar at the present time I see no need of his immediate presence in harbor and I shall probably cable him to this effect, upon his arrival at Aden on the 26th inst. recommending that he time his arrival at Zanzibar not later than the first of May.

I have the honor to be
Sir
Your obedient servant
Seth A. Pratt
U.S. Consul
